moves.1. e4: In this game I was holding DJ for most of the game. Then my greed gets the better of me, I take a poisoned pawn and it is quickly lost.
moves.1... c5: So I play my usual Sicilian
moves.2... Nc6: and I follow the main line
moves.3. Nc3: What is this? is he intending a closed variation after all?
moves.4. d4: He opts for the open variation
moves.5... Nf6: And we reach the usual position
moves.6. Bb5: This is slightly unusual, Bg5, Bc4 and Be2 are more common
moves.6... Bd7: I have to defend my knight
moves.7. h3: This seems a little strange, I'm still not sure why he played it
moves.7... g6: As he has avoided the sharpest variations such as the Yugoslav attack, I may as well fianchetto my bf8
moves.10. Nf3: I am not sure why he played this either, he seems to be going backwards. This position has been reached before, but there is no games with Nf3 on the Gameknot World Database, but there is on the database of Gameknot games.
moves.10... a6: a6 is often a move played in the Open Sicilian. Here I can play it with tempo.
moves.11... b5: Qa5 was the move played in the only other game on the Gameknot opening databases (ojdol (2167) vs. janhalpha (2323) - drawn in 32 moves. This move seemed more thematic - pursuing a minority attack against the white queen side.
moves.12... Na5: With the idea of coming in to c4 at some stage
moves.13. Qd2: He doubles up on the diagonal
moves.13... Re8: I move the rook, so Be3-h6 can be met with Bg7-h8
moves.14. b4: He hits my knight, but leaves his c pawn backwards on a semi-open file. He does this before I can play Rc8 enabling me to recapture on c4 with the rook
moves.15... bxc4: I take back. Now his weak c2 pawn is shielded by my pawn, but I felt I was doing ok here
moves.16... Bh8: Mine retreats, as prepared by Rf8-e8
moves.17... Bc6: I put more pressure on the e pawn.
moves.18... Qc7: I plan to put my queen on b7 with more pressure on e4
moves.20. Rd2: Again, I am not quite sure why he played this
moves.20... Rec8: I improve the standing of my other rook. Now if I can distract him on the centre and/or queen side his Bh6 may proof to be misplaced.
moves.23... a5: I try to do something on the queen side
moves.24. Re1: He improves the position of his rook. My e pawn is now slightly weak, open to attack down the semi-open e file and unable to move without being taken. Of course e7-e5 at any time will be met with dxe6 en passant.
moves.25... Rb5: I attack the d5 pawn again.
moves.26. Qf3: He puts another protector on it.
moves.26... Qb7: and I increase the pressure on d5
moves.27. Rde4: He gangs up on my e pawn. Of course I can't play Nf6xe4 as he replies Qxf7 mate!
moves.28. Rf4: What is this? He is leaving the d pawn with only one defender and I have 3 pieces attacking it. Can't he see I can just take on d5?
moves.28... Qxd5: So I take, but it is a massive mistake, I have missed a clever tactical point
moves.29. Rxf6: Of course! Now if e7xf6 then Re1-e8 is mate! If Bxf6, then Qxf6!! mates. See http://gameknot.com/chess-puzzle.pl?pz=105923
moves.30. Rxf3: But of course he takes back with the rook, and I am just knight for pawn down
moves.30... f5: My f7 pawn was attacked by knight and rook, so I had to move it to save it!
moves.31. g4: At last I see the point of h2-h3!
moves.32. gxf5: He takes - he is opening up my king side.
moves.35... Rc5: I offer an exchange of rooks.
moves.37. Ne4: Knight forks my pawns and bishop f6
moves.41. Be3:
He hits my c pawn, and I have had enough. It is pretty hopeless for black now.

Many thanks for reading this, please rate it on the start system, and leave a comment or two, so that I know how I am doing with my annotations.
